original: HAMMAR, Hugo Gilius Eugen, Doktor Ing:, Göteborg, f Repplinge, Öland, 4/3 64 av här.skriv C H o Charlotta Björklund, gm (2) Cyssie Svensson. Studex Kalm 83, skpbyggm.ex CTH 88, prakt Frankr 87, Engl o USA 88—96. övering o dir.ass Lindholmens verkst 96—06, övering Gbgs nya verkst AB 06, vkst dir v dess ombildn t AB Götaverken 10—38. Ordf navig.-sk i Gbg, styr.led CTH, ordf i dess nybyggn.-komm, i nmdn f stat skeppsprovn.anst, stdsflm i Gbg 14—19, styr.led Gbgs jub.utställn 23 o i arb.utsk, ordf sjöf- o exp.utsk. Sakk i be-redn f ordn av: Sv utrikesrepr 07, ångfärje-förb m Tyskl 08, sv jvgstax 08, 11 års tulltaxa 09, tillförs av valsvksprodukter 16—20 o Finska stat isbryt.fråg 20 samt sakk i försv.-kommiss 34. Medl komm f: modernis av fi varv i Kkrona 14, do f bygg av hdlsfartyg 16—17, utredn rör flottstn i Sthlms skärg 17, CTH omorg 19 o 34—35, ind demokrati 20, örlogsvarvens org 29, förflyttn av Sthlms ör-logsstn 30, CTH skeppsbygg.instit (ordf) 36— 39 samt led stat ind.kommiss 14—19, inst f långfrist kredit åt när.livet 34 o ordf 36 års studexsakk. Styr.ordf AB Victory, El svetsn.-AB, AB Gbgs skeppsdockor, red.AB Transmark o Transocean, v. styr.ordf Götaverken, AB Gilius o Arb.giv ömsesid ol.f.frn. Resor: De fi europ länd 00—38, Panama o USA 24, USA 25, Egypt o Nordafr 30, Västind o Sydamer 31, Västafr 33, Mindre Asien 34, Sydafr 35, Hawaii 36, Brasil 37. Av trycket: Chapmans inflyt på fartygskonstr utveckl, John Ericssons Monitor o drabbn på Hampt Roads, Fartygstyper i Sv Ostind Comp flotta, Fr Ölands älvar t livets 37, Som emigr i USA 38 samt avhandl i in- o utl facktidskr. Kmstk-NO, KVOlkl, KNS :tOOmkr, KFinlVRO2kl, John EricsM g, MCsiIRg, Svarta örnsM g, ProPGM, IVAstGM, dr ing h c 29, LVVS, Det Kongl Vidensk Selsk Trondheim, l.LKrVA, hed.led IVA, ÖS, Sv teknol.frn, Frn Gbgs sjöf.mus, John Ericson Soc, Amer Soc of Swed Engineers, Rotary, ölandskl i Sthlm, Smål.-gillet i Gbg, Kalm nät i Upps o Lund, Gbgs nät i Upps, Gbgs segelsällsk, Sv växtgeogr sällk, led av Soc of Nåväl Architects, Lond, Soc of Nåväl Arch & Marineng, New York, Schiffbautechn Gesellsch, Berlin, Royal Soc of Arts, Lond, Bachelors Club, Gbg.
translated: HAMMAR, Hugo Gilius Eugen, Doctor of Engineering, Gothenburg, born in Repplinge, Öland, on March 4, 1864, son of C. H. and Charlotta Björklund, married (2) Cyssie Svensson. Graduated from Kalm 1883, apprentice shipbuilder at CTH 1888, practical experience in France 1887 and England and USA 1888-1896. Chief engineer and assistant manager at Lindholmens Workshop 1896-1906, chief engineer at Gothenburg's new workshop AB 1906, workshop director during its restructuring into AB Götaverken 1910-1938. Chairman of the Navigation School in Gothenburg, board member of CTH, chairman of its new construction committee, member of the committee for the state ship testing facility, chairman of the committee for the Gothenburg Centennial Exhibition 1923 and of the labor committee, chairman of the shipping and export committee, and expert in the committee for the arrangements of: Swedish Foreign Representation 1907, steam ferry association with Germany 1908, Swedish railway tariffs 1908, 1911 customs tariff, supply of whale products 1916-1920, and Finnish state icebreaker issues 1920; and expert in the defense commission in 1934. Member of the municipal committee for: modernization of naval yards in Karlskrona 1914, construction of merchant vessels 1916-1917, investigation regarding naval bases in Stockholm's archipelago 1917, CTH reorganization in 1919 and 1934-1935, democratization of the navy 1920, organization of naval yards 1929, transfer of Stockholm's naval station 1930, chairman of the CTH shipbuilding institute 1936-1939, and member of the state industrial commission 1914-1919, institute for long-term credit for the business sector 1934, and chairman of the 1936 examination committee. Chairman of the board for AB Victory, El welding AB, AB Gothenburg Ship Docks, editor for AB Transmark and Transocean, vice chairman of Götaverken, AB Gilius, and Arb. Stockholm Mutual Insurance Company. Travelled extensively throughout Europe from 1900 to 1938, Panama and USA in 1924, USA in 1925, Egypt and North Africa in 1930, West Indies and South America in 1931, West Africa in 1933, Asia Minor in 1934, South Africa in 1935, Hawaii in 1936, and Brazil in 1937. Author of several publications including: Chapman's influence on shipbuilding development, John Ericsson's Monitor and the battle at Hampton Roads, Types of ships in the Swedish East India Company's fleet, Life on the rivers of Öland, Emigration in the USA in 1938, and papers in national and international professional journals. Member of: Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, Royal Vasa Order Commander 1st Class, Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav Knight, Order of the Cross of Liberty 2nd Class (Finland), John Ericsson Medal in gold, Knight of the Royal Order of Seraphim, Black Eagle of Mälaren City, Pro Patriot, member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences, honorary member of the Royal Swedish Society of Naval Sciences, Öland Technical Society, Swedish Society for Plant Geography, and member of the Society of Naval Architects in London, the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers in New York, the Schiffbautechnischen Gesellschaft in Berlin, the Royal Society of Arts in London, the Bachelors Club in Gothenburg.
